cards.Front: Define 'diet'.
cards.Back: The foods habitually eaten by an individual or group.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'dietary pattern' (USDA).
cards.Back: The quantities, proportions, variety, or combination of different foods, drinks, and nutrients in diets, and the frequency with which they are habitually consumed.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'healthy diet' (WHO/USDA).
cards.Back: High in fruits, vegetables, legumes, nuts, and grains; lower in salt, free sugars, and fats (especially saturated and trans fats); nutritionally adequate to maintain weight, supply energy, and reduce disease risk.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'nutrition'.
cards.Back: The study of foods and food substances that help animals (and plants) grow and stay healthy. Food provides energy (calories) and nutrients; nutrition science also examines behaviors and social factors related to food choices.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: What is 'dietary intake'?
cards.Back: The consumption of specific foods and food components that comprise an individual's diet.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: What are 'Dietary Reference Intakes (DRIs)'?
cards.Back: Values issued by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Academies that represent current knowledge on nutrient needs of healthy populations; individual needs may be higher or lower.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA).
cards.Back: Intake that meets the needs of 97–98% of healthy individuals of a given age and sex.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Adequate Intake (AI).
cards.Back: A recommended intake based on observed or experimentally determined approximations when an RDA cannot be determined.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL).
cards.Back: The highest daily intake unlikely to pose risk of adverse health effects; intake above the UL increases risk of adverse effects.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Daily Value (DV) on labels.
cards.Back: Standardized reference amounts used on labels, expressed as a percentage per serving toward a daily level; often similar to RDA or AI but not always.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'nutrient-dense' foods
cards.Back: Foods high in nutrients and relatively low in calories, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat or fat-free milk products, seafood, lean meats, eggs, peas, beans, and nuts.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'nutrient-poor, energy-dense' foods.
cards.Back: Foods high in calories but low in essential nutrients; overconsumption is linked with overweight/obesity, type 2 diabetes, and some cancers; common in Western countries.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Name the three macronutrients and primary roles.
cards.Back: Carbohydrates: primary energy source. Protein: structural and functional roles (enzymes, carriers, hormones). Fat: structural membrane components, signaling, energy storage.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Simple vs complex carbohydrates.
cards.Back: Simple carbohydrates are sugars; complex carbohydrates include starches and fiber.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Starch—what is it?
cards.Back: A complex carbohydrate composed of glucose units; a major storage form of carbohydrate in plants.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Sugars—what are they?
cards.Back: Simple carbohydrates that provide energy; naturally present in fruits and milk and added to many processed foods.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Dietary fiber—key points.
cards.Back: Found only in plants; improves laxation and satiety, lowers coronary heart disease risk, and helps maintain normal glucose.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Soluble fiber—physiology & sources.
cards.Back: Forms viscous solutions that can slow gastric emptying and help lower LDL cholesterol; found in oats, barley, legumes, and many fruits.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Insoluble fiber—physiology & sources.
cards.Back: Adds bulk and speeds transit through the gut; found in whole grains and many vegetables.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Adult fiber intake targets.
cards.Back: Approximately 14 g per 1,000 kcal; about 38 g/day for men and 25 g/day for women.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Complete vs incomplete proteins.
cards.Back: Complete proteins contain all essential amino acids in needed amounts; incomplete proteins lack one or more in needed proportions.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Which plant protein is complete?
cards.Back: Soy protein contains all nine essential amino acids in adequate amounts.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Essential amino acids—original source.
cards.Back: Plants and microbes are the original source of essential amino acids.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Protein digestion & absorption (overview).
cards.Back: Proteins are broken down by stomach acid and proteases into amino acids, which are absorbed and rebuilt into body proteins as needed.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Protein RDA and typical % of energy.
cards.Back: RDA is 0.8 g/kg/day. Example: ~55 g/day (~10–11% of 2000 kcal) for a 150 lb adult.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Plant foods and protein adequacy.
cards.Back: Varied whole plant foods easily meet protein requirements, especially with legumes, grains, and greens.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Protein combining at meals—necessary?
cards.Back: No; eating a variety of plant foods over time provides a complete amino acid profile.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Animal protein and acid load (bone concern).
cards.Back: High animal protein intake may contribute to diet-derived metabolic acidosis, with calcium mobilized from bone to buffer acid (area of active study).
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Saturated fat—general guidance.
cards.Back: Limit saturated fat; high intake is common in Western dietary patterns.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Monounsaturated fats (MUFA).
cards.Back: Present in foods such as olive oil, nuts, and avocados.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Polyunsaturated fats (PUFA).
cards.Back: Include essential fatty acids; found in nuts, seeds, and certain plant oils.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Omega-6 (linoleic acid) daily intake.
cards.Back: Men: 17 g/day; Women: 12 g/day.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Omega-3 (alpha-linolenic acid) daily intake.
cards.Back: Men: 1.6 g/day; Women: 1.1 g/day.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Trans fat—status & avoidance.
cards.Back: Avoid partially hydrogenated oils; industrial trans fats have been largely removed from the food supply.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Cholesterol—dietary note.
cards.Back: Cholesterol is found in animal-derived foods; dietary patterns emphasize plant-predominant choices.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Why micronutrients matter.
cards.Back: They enable cellular metabolism and act as cofactors; deficiencies or excesses impair health.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Whole foods vs supplements for micronutrients.
cards.Back: Nutrient-dense whole foods are preferred; supplements do not consistently replicate benefits and can sometimes cause harm.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Vitamin D—special consideration.
cards.Back: Few foods naturally contain vitamin D; many adults have low levels, so supplementation is often needed with low sun exposure.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Vitamin B12—special consideration.
cards.Back: Not reliably present in plants; fortified foods or supplements are recommended for plant-based eaters.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Iron—forms and absorption.
cards.Back: Heme iron is more readily absorbed; non‑heme iron absorption improves with vitamin C. Plant sources include legumes, greens, whole grains, nuts, and seeds.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Calcium—plant-based sources & caveat.
cards.Back: Use fortified plant milks/yogurts, calcium‑set tofu, and low‑oxalate leafy greens; spinach and similar high‑oxalate greens have poor calcium bioavailability.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Iodine—plant-based note.
cards.Back: Plants provide little iodine unless soil is iodine‑rich; iodized salt or sea vegetables can supply iodine.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Antioxidants—role and examples.
cards.Back: Neutralize free radicals and reduce oxidative stress. Examples include vitamin C, vitamin E, carotenoids, selenium, and zinc.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Potassium—dietary message.
cards.Back: Commonly low intake; plant foods such as beans, potatoes, leafy greens, squash, bananas, and other fruits/vegetables provide potassium.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Zinc—plant sources note.
cards.Back: Legumes, nuts, seeds, and whole grains provide zinc; traditional preparation (soaking/sprouting) can improve availability.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Macronutrient energy values (kcal per gram)
cards.Back: Carbohydrates: 4 kcal/g · Protein: 4 kcal/g · Fat: 9 kcal/g.
cards.Section: Foundational Background

cards.Front: Define 'Underconsumed nutrient or food component'.
cards.Back: A nutrient or food component that is underconsumed by 5% or more of the population or in specific groups relative to the EAR, AI or other quantitative authoritative recommendations from the diet alone. Used to replace the term 'shortfall nutrient.'
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Define 'Overconsumed nutrient or food component'.
cards.Back: A nutrient or food component that is consumed in potential excess of the UL, CDRR, or other quantitative authoritative recommendations by 5% or more of the population or in specific groups from the diet alone.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Define 'Nutrient or food component of public health concern'.
cards.Back: Underconsumed and overconsumed nutrients or food components with supporting evidence through biochemical indices or functional status indicators, plus evidence that inadequacy or excess is directly related to a specific health condition, indicating public health relevance.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List examples of added sugars as they appear on labels.
cards.Back: Cane sugar, high fructose corn syrup, fructose, sucrose, dextrose, lactose, honey, brown sugar, turbinado sugar, beet sugar, raw sugar, malt syrup, maltose, rice syrup, agave, molasses, Florida crystals, fruit juice, and others.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What proportion of calories comes from added sugars in US adults and children > 6 years?
cards.Back: Approximately 14.1% of total calories.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What is the WHO recommendation for added sugar intake?
cards.Back: Both adults and children should limit daily consumption of added sugar to less than 10% of total calories (less than 200 kcal in a 2,000 kcal diet; up to 12 teaspoons or 48 g), with a goal of less than 5% (less than 100 kcal; up to 6 teaspoons or 24 g).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What is the AHA recommendation for added sugar intake?
cards.Back: Maximum of 100 kcal (6 teaspoons or 24 g) per day for women, children, and teens; no more than 150 kcal (9 teaspoons or 36 g) per day for men.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List top sources of added sugar in the US diet.
cards.Back: Sugar-sweetened beverages, breads/rolls/tortillas, sweet bakery products, coffee and tea, sugars (honey, syrups, jams), fats and oils (salad dressings, condiments), ready-to-eat cereals, other prepared foods.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What is the AHA recommendation for saturated fat intake?
cards.Back: Limit saturated fat intake to no more than 5–6% of total calories.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in saturated fat.
cards.Back: Higher fat cuts of beef, pork, lamb; salami; sausages; processed meats; fast foods (e.g., cheeseburgers); lard; butter; cheese; coconut oil; palm oil; palm kernel oil.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List plant foods containing notable saturated fat.
cards.Back: Nuts and seeds (typically 1–2 g per oz, Brazil nuts highest), avocados (2.1 g per 100 g), plant oils (1–2 g per tablespoon, coconut oil 12 g/tbsp, palm oil 7 g/tbsp).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Top 5 sources of saturated fat in US adult diets (by % contribution).
cards.Back: Cheese (16.5%), beef (9.1%), other fats and oils (8.9%), milk (6.7%), frankfurters/sausages/luncheon meats (6.7%).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What proportion of sodium intake comes from mixed dishes?
cards.Back: Almost 50%, including burgers, sandwiches, tacos, rice/pasta/grain dishes, pizza, meat/poultry/seafood dishes, and soups.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List sources of sodium in the US diet (percent contributions).
cards.Back: Added outside the home (70.9%), inherent to food (14.2%), added in home preparation (5.6%), added at the table (4.9%).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Counseling tip: What is Jeff Novick’s sodium rule of thumb?
cards.Back: If sodium per serving (mg) ≤ kcal per serving, someone eating 2,300 kcal/day will keep salt intake ≈2,300 mg/day or less.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What sodium intake defines 'low sodium'?
cards.Back: Less than 1,500 mg/day.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What is the AHA stance on dietary cholesterol?
cards.Back: Food-based dietary guidance should emphasize overall dietary patterns inherently low in cholesterol.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in cholesterol.
cards.Back: Eggs, dairy, cheese, organ meats, shellfish, other meats including poultry and fish.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Top sources of cholesterol in the US diet (with %).
cards.Back: Meat (42%: 12% poultry, 12% mixed dishes, 8% red meat, 5% processed meat, 5% seafood), eggs (25%), grain products (17%), milk and products (11%).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What did the FDA declare about trans fats?
cards.Back: The FDA declared trans fatty acids unsafe for human consumption and mandated removal from food. All manufacturing of artificial trans fats ended January 1, 2021.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What health outcome improved after removal of industrial trans fats?
cards.Back: Associated with decreased cardiovascular risk, such as ischemic heart disease.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods where trans fats are found.
cards.Back: Partially hydrogenated plant oils (processed foods), naturally in some meat and dairy products. Examples: animal foods (especially red/processed meats), butter (~10% of butter’s total fat), refined grain products (doughnuts, cookies, crackers, muffins, pies, cakes).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: Which foods/beverages are listed as Group 1 carcinogens to humans?
cards.Back: Alcoholic beverages and processed meats.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List nutrients underconsumed by the entire population.
cards.Back: Calcium*, choline, fiber*, magnesium, potassium*, vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin D*, vitamin E, vitamin K. (* = nutrients of public health concern).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in calcium (%DV examples).
cards.Back: ¼ cup cheese, ¼ cup tofu with calcium sulfate, ½ cup soybeans, 1 cup enriched cornmeal, 4 oz fortified plant milks, 1 cup cooked spinach/collards.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in fiber (%DV examples).
cards.Back: ½ cup black beans, ½ cup split peas, ½ cup lentils, ½ avocado, ½ cup raspberries, 7 dried figs, 3 tbsp flaxseed, 1 cup oatmeal, 1 cup whole-wheat pasta.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in magnesium (%DV examples).
cards.Back: 4 Brazil nuts; 1 oz almonds, cashews, or pine nuts; 2 oz peanuts; 1 oz cooked spinach; ½ cup amaranth; ¾ cup edamame; 2 oz dark chocolate.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in potassium (%DV examples).
cards.Back: 1 small baked potato, ½ cup yams, ½ avocado, ½ cup beans (white, adzuki, soy, black turtle, lima), 1 cup mashed banana, ½ cup beet greens, 5 dried apricots or dates.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in vitamin A (%DV examples).
cards.Back: ½ cup cooked sweet potato or spinach, ½ cup raw carrots, 1 cup cantaloupe or butternut squash. (Beef liver: 4 oz exceeds UL 3,000 µg).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in vitamin C (%DV examples).
cards.Back: ½ cup bok choy, parsley, daikon radish, broccoli, cantaloupe, Brussels sprouts, pineapple, cabbage, mustard greens, papaya, green peas, kale, tomatoes, strawberries, turnip greens, oranges, guava, kiwi, mango, red peppers.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in vitamin D (%DV examples).
cards.Back: ½ cup salmon or other high-fat fish, 1 cup fortified milk (dairy or nondairy), 1 cup fortified cereals.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods high in vitamin E (%DV examples).
cards.Back: 1 oz sunflower seeds, almonds, or hazelnuts; 1 tbsp sunflower or safflower oils; 1 small trout fillet (113 g).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What are the top food groups to consume based on nutrients per kcal?
cards.Back: Vegetables (including mushrooms), herbs and spices, fruits, legumes, whole grains, nuts, seeds.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: List foods to avoid/limit based on calorie density and low nutrient density.
cards.Back: Sugar-sweetened beverages, desserts/sweet snacks, sandwiches (esp. with processed meats), added oils from tropical plants (coconut, palm kernel, palm oil), added fats (butter, shortening, lard), fried foods, red and processed meats (hot dogs, sausages, ham, luncheon meats), refined grains (white).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – Assess food intake patterns and nutrients of deficit and excess

cards.Front: What is the key principle when evaluating the healthfulness of a food?
cards.Back: Think beyond a single nutrient and consider the entire 'food package.' A food may be high in one nutrient but unhealthy overall if the rest of the package is not ideal.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: Give an example of a food that is a top source of a nutrient but also a top source of a harmful component.
cards.Back: Whole-fat and 2% milk are top sources of calcium but also top sources of saturated fat.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: What is the key counseling question when considering nutrient sources?
cards.Back: Ask: 'Is there a better source or package to get these nutrients?'
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: Define whole foods according to the patient-facing statement.
cards.Back: Whole foods are unrefined or minimally processed in such a way as to not substantially diminish their nutrient content. Frozen vegetables are not considered refined foods.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: What is a simple way to identify a whole food?
cards.Back: Whole foods often have no ingredient list because they are single ingredient foods (e.g., an apple or a carrot).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: How can visualization help determine if something is a whole food?
cards.Back: If you can easily imagine everything that has happened to the food before eating it, it is likely a whole food (e.g., an apple picked, cleaned, shipped). In contrast, apple-flavored candy is processed.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: Example: How does an apple progress from whole to highly processed?
cards.Back: Apple → applesauce → apple juice → apple fritter.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: What is the general rule about whole foods and nutrition?
cards.Back: Generally, the more whole the food (the less processed), the more nutritious it is.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: What is Michael Pollan’s signature summary guideline?
cards.Back: "Eat food, not too much, mostly plants." Food = unprocessed natural foods; Not too much = appropriate portion sizes; Mostly plants = diet should consist mostly of plants (doesn’t require vegan/vegetarian).
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: Which food groups should be emphasized according to general principles?
cards.Back: Legumes, vegetables, fruits, whole-grains, nuts, and seeds.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: What does 'Eat a rainbow every day' mean?
cards.Back: It refers to eating a variety of plants of different colors, which come from different flavonoids and vitamins essential to disease prevention and health.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume

cards.Front: How does 'eating a rainbow' support nutrition adequacy?
cards.Back: Consuming a wide variety of plant foods daily allows most people to meet macronutrient and micronutrient needs, with possible supplementation for vitamins B12 and D.
cards.Section: Objective 1 – General principles on foods to consume
